none: Translated title: Fāʼidah to protect against iron
Part of the Maktaba grant project (Local Note)
In Arabic in Maghrebi style script and Hausa in Ajami. (Language Note)
Arabic Manuscripts from West Africa--The ‘Umar Falke Collection
Fāʼidah to protect against iron for seven days.
فائدة الحديد : لايقطع أبدا و لو كان في نوم لا يقطع جسدك أبدا إن شاء الله بالله الذي إلا هو لا يصيبك سبعة أيام.

This rare collection of manuscripts dates back to the 19th and 20th centuries and come from mainly northern Nigeria (Kano in particular) but also includes items from Ghana, Senegal and Mali. Mostly handwritten in Arabic and Ajami scripts, these manuscripts cover a wide range of subjects from Arabic grammar, history, theology, law and astronomy to name a few, with particular strength in Tijâniyya Sufi order and Hausa poetry.   Comprised of 5,000 items, the manuscripts are split across four separate collections and serve as an excellent example of West African literacy in Arabic:  The 'Umar Falke Collection, The John Paden Collection, The John Hunwick Collection, The University of Ghana Collection

body.value:
بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم 

صلى الله على النبي الكريم فائد الحديد  

لا تقطع أبدا، ولو كان في نوم لا يقطع جسدك أبدا 

إن شاء الله، بالله الذي لا إله إلا هو لا يصيبك سبعة  

أيام كتبه وتشرب والغسل مع شجرة زُوُو ⁖ 

مع شجر طاميا ⁖ مع شجر قَنَيَا ⁖ مع شجر 

كَوْثِ بَغَارُو ⁖ مع شجر سَمْسَمِي ⁖ مع 

الحجر تسمى قومكِرارَى وثلاثَ مغُود ⁖ و 

لقد جاءكم رسول من أنفسكم عزيز عليه 

ما عنتم حريص عليكم ⁖ بالمؤمنين رؤوف 

رحيم ⁖ فإن تولوا فقل حسبي الله لا إله إلا  

هو عليه توكلت وهو رب العرش العظيم 

يا هحححهيهيل ⁖ يا الحححهيهل ⁖  

يا هجيلهيهل ⁖ يا عههجيهيهل ⁖ 

يا الحجيهيل ⁖ يا كجيلهيل ⁖  

يا سههجيهيهيهل ⁖ يامعهجيهيل ⁖

***Fāʼida* to Protect against Iron**

*Translated by Paul Naylor*

In the name of God, the Most Gracious the Most Merciful. *Fāʾida* of iron: it will not cut ever, even during sleep it will not cut your body ever if God wills, by the God whom there is no God save Him. It will not hurt you. (For) seven days write it, drink and wash \[your body\] with the *zuwo* tree,[^1] *tsamiya,*[^2] *kanya*,[^3] *kauci bagaruwa*,[^4] and *samsami*[^5] and a rock called *kwan maƙera*[^6] and three *magudi*[^7] and \[the verses\]: "There certainly has come to you a messenger from among yourselves. He is concerned by your suffering, anxious for your well-being, and gracious and merciful to the believers. But if they turn away, then say, God is sufficient for me. There is no god except Him. In Him I put my trust. And He is the Lord of the Mighty Throne.'"[^8]

> Oh Haḥaḥaḥahayahīlu, oh al-Ḥaḥaḥahayhilu, Oh Hajayalhīhilu, Oh 'Ahahajayhahīlu, oh al-Ḥajayhīlu, Oh Kajaylahīlu, oh Sahahajayhayhayhīlu, Oh Ma'ahajayahīlu.[^9]

[^1]: *Celtis integrifolia*, a type of hackberry.

[^2]: Tamarind.

[^3]: *Kanya* is a plant in the *Commelinaceae* or dayflower family. See Emmanuel Izaka Aigbokhan, *Annotated Checklist of Vascular Plants of Southern Nigeria* (University of Benin Press, 2014).

[^4]: Acacia roots.

[^5]: A leaf that used to be smoked like tobacco.

[^6]: Literally "egg of the blacksmiths," it is the "stone" that forms on the spot where the bellow used by the blacksmiths blows. It is made of a mixture of charcoal dust, as well as the liquefied metals (iron, silver) that were worked by the blacksmith. The "stone" can be used to produce inks for writing on paper.

[^7]: Bargery gives the meaning as "a large ring of small sticks, &c., tied together for use in strengthening the frames of a thatched roof." See G.P. Bargery and D. Westermann, *A Hausa-English Dictionary and English-Hausa Vocabulary* (London: Oxford University Press, 1934).

[^8]: Qurʾan 9:128-9. English translations of the Qurʾan are from Mustafa Khattab, *The Clear Quran: A Thematic English Translation of the Message of the Final Revelation* (Lombard, IL: Book of Signs Foundation, 2016).

[^9]: Names of "rūḥānīyāt" (spiritual entities from the angelic realm) recognizable by the ending in -il (or -īl), such as Jibrīl (Gabriel), Mikāʼīl (Michael) etc.
